"Fifth, even if these important measures do materialize, they are ultimately peripheral to resolving the real problem in the South China Sea. Of course, rules and norms are important to provide a common set of guidelines for all actors, and hotlines are useful when crises break out (provided, of course, that the phones are actually answered, as previous instances in the U.S.-China relationship have demonstrated). But the fundamental challenge in the South China Sea has not been the shortage of rules or the absence of crisis management mechanisms, but the rise of a bolder, more assertive China that is so committed to changing the status quo in its favor that it is willing to break existing rules and risk a crisis in the process. In that sense, hotlines or codes of conduct are of limited utility unless they are accompanied by a change in Beijing’s calculations and resulting approach.

Author Langner (2016) states that:
Millions of words have been expended on China's debt problem. Two points need making: The danger is Asia-wide. And if an implosion is coming, it's most likely in the next three years.
1.	Nonfinancial corporations in the region face a string of record offshore maturities from now until 2019 -- a total $219.7 billion of bonds denominated in dollars and euros is due between January 2017 and December 2019.
Crunch Time
Asian nonfinancial companies must repay a record $87 billion of global bonds in 2019. Chinese firms owe $50.8 billion of that debt was issued over the past three years. Since March 2013, currencies across Asia have dropped, in some cases by double digits.
1.	The obvious outcome of this cocktail is a lot of defaults. While they have picked up in the past two years, low interest rates from the U.S. to Japan have impeded a worst-case scenario. For all that, the $3.3 billion of notes with missed coupons this year is already the highest level since 2012. 
Lost Wallet
The amount of offshore notes on which Asian companies missed payments has been rising steadily
1.	It's only going to get worse. Even with record monetary stimulus everywhere, companies in Asia face a host of challenges, from a slowing economy in China that's dragging the whole region down, to shrinking profit margins.

Beijing has firmly rejected demands by U.S. authorities to “stop” construction or militarization of its holdings in the South China Sea. China appears equally determined to demonstrate that however much countries in Asia may resent it, they are incapable of impeding Beijing's pursuit of control over the critical maritime space. It is no coincidence that China has loudly promoted the potential economic gains of its “One Belt, One Road” and other regional economic initiatives at the same time that it has pushed its coercive, but so far non-violent expansion of control over the South China Sea. U.S. efforts to build international pressure through joint patrols and promotion of arbitration through international courts represent the right way to counter China's moves. However, determining the appropriate level of international pressure to dissuade Beijing remains a worryingly elusive task."

There is a 35% chance that China will declare an Air-Defense Identification Zone (ADIZ) over any part of the South China Sea before October 1, 2016. An ADIZ requires aircrafts to properly identify themselves to the government to whose country they are entering. China’s bond with the countries in Southeast Asia would be ruined if China declared an ADIZ in the South China Sea. Also, Beijing almost has full control over the maritime enterprises in the South China Sea and declaring an ADIZ would not show a desire for sovereignty.

Recent events in China, the recent letter calling for the removal of President Xi, leads me to believe that Xi may not impose an ADIZ zone this year until he is able to solidify his standing within the party.  If he does, he may still impose the ADIZ, but it will come at a later date.

Even though the act doesn't seem to help China in any way (and may strain tensions with nearby nations), it has lots of support from Chinese forces (like the People's Liberation Army and the Communist Party). This might cause it to be declared, but, based on China's inability to enforce the region, it is more likely it will not be created.

While the creation of an ADIZ over the South China Sea would aggravate their allies, China did recently establish an ADIZ in the East China Sea, increasing the likelihood of another one being created. However, most likely the strategic advantages of creating an ADIZ in the South China Sea will not be enough to risk angering allies in Southeast Asia.

ADIZ is an area over land or water where planes need to identify themselves or else they will be shot down. China made one over the East China Sea unexpectedly in 2013. US has been increasing naval presence in South China Sea. Communist Army has full control over China’s decision and in general has aggressive stances on political issues. On the other hand, Most analysts in China believe that East Sea ADIZ was pointless and South Sea would be pointless as well. It is now expected and will not surprise people anymore. I would say that it is a 40% chance of happening because of the precedence they have set with the ADIZ in the East China Sea.

Despite China's 2013 decision to form an Air-Defense Identification Zone over the East China Sea, I see a very low probability of there being one formed above the South China Sea any time soon. Their previous decision seemed to have come in response to the AirSea Battle Doctrine (renamed the Joint Concept for Access and Maneuver in the Global Commons), where the Navy and the Air Force worked together on plans to enable the U.S. government to be able to defeat adversaries who had the capability of denying the U.S. access to a certain region of their territory. This is most certainly the case with China as the U.S. has put a lot of stock into enabling free travel within the waterways around China for sailors of all backgrounds, inherently allowing the U.S. a greater chance of navigating these regions in order to properly prepare for a conflict. However, China claims that this act was in order to create newfound sovereignty in the East China Sea, as they lacked any control over the Diaoyu Islands, a characteristic that is not shared with the South China Sea. However, they have no way that they can attribute this decision to sovereignty for the South China Sea as Beijing has nearly full control over all of the maritime enterprises in the South China Sea. In fact, instead of showing a desire for sovereignty, it would just weaken the great relations China has with the countries in Southeast Asia due to border conflicts regarding the edge of the ADIZ in relationship to the island provinces that China and its neighbors currently control. Because of how these islands lie within the South China Sea, making a fair border is quite the challenging task as many of the islands are within a very close vicinity of islands belonging to other countries. Lastly, most analysts within China agree that the formulation of an Air-Defense Identification Zone wouldn't do anything productive for China, and could just serve as a way to aggravate those countries around them.
Yes, they will declare one. No, they can't enforce it. Judging to ensue.

It's not just Vietnam employing ADS-B.  This will be a standard among all aviation communities.  Especially in Asia.  Check out the commercial routes in Asia below.  Another option for China that has not been discussed is an MOA.  An MOA is a military operations area.  An MOA is designated on aviation sectional maps as special use airspace.  I can fly my aircraft though MOAs all day long.  But some MOAs have warnings such as "be careful of fast low flying aircraft" or "missile range" or "powerful laser".  The other option China has is setting up controlled airspace around their man-made islands.  For example, most controlled airspace around busy airports have class B airspace.  San Fransisco International Airport (SFO) is class B airspace.  Before I fly into class B airspace I need to be "Cleared".  Bottom line is if China wants to be wise about it's airspace they will start by applying controlled airspace gradually.  They will publish a sectional chart of their islands as controlled Class E, D, C, or B airspace and maybe set up an MOA with instructions.

Much has been made of the US / Japanese military flights through China's E China Sea ADIZ and how they made the ADIZ declaration premature and a failure of policy by China. But China continues to monitor and even enforce the ADIZ with foreign civilian aircraft,who oblige.  Just because China cannot enforce the ADIZ with foreign military aircraft doesn't make the ADIZ useless or a mistake. The ADIZ is acknowledged commercially now and China will be able to enforce it militarily in time as it becomes more powerful militarily and economically.  
China is now moving quickly to open Woody Island in S China Sea to regular commercial flights. It seems likely to me that China will use a S China Sea ADIZ to enforce civilian flights in the same manner. In time they can enforce it militarily, and in the meantime who is going to remove, blockade or otherwise prevent their island(s) buildup? China doesn't have to dominate the US and Japan militarily before the ADIZ is useful. This isn't about domination through war - China knows Japan and the US will not attack or blockade any of its disputed islands. It's about establishing a "civilian" foothold on the ground, in the sea and in the air that is consistent with its claim of the S China Sea as Chinese national territory. Commercial flights would acknowledge and adhere to S China Sea ADIZ, and eventually the military will enforce it also.
Whether it will happen by Oct 2016  or not is less certain, but I believe there's more than a decent chance.

China is likely to declare an Air-Defense Identification Zone (ADIZ) over its claimed areas of the South China Sea within the next year.  Territorial disputes that have existed over the past decade continued to present and are almost certain to continue into 2016 as well.  China’s military build-up since 2012 suggests it is likely preparing itself for enforcement of an ADIZ over the South China Sea.  Andrew Erickson, a professor at the U.S. Naval War College, claims that the most logical application of the military facilities in the Fiery Cross Reefs is to support an ADIZ.  Since China has significant military and economic advantages over the other Asian nations involved in the South China Sea conflict, but does not advantages over the U.S. in terms of aerial military power, it is likely to declare an ADIZ, because it is the only option where it can display military and territorial dominance over its Asian adversaries.

This is a tough question. Part of South China Sea directly abuts China's coastline, so would be very reasonable that that area would be designated ADIZ. From China's point of view, they have been aggressive lately in their territorial claims, but an ADIZ is a formal declaration. If it is too wide and is routinely violated, then it will mandate a battlefield response. Which is actually bad for everybody. IF the ADIZ is too narrow, then it appears to undercut the recent territorial claims. To me, it seems that they will establish an ADIZ off their direct coast and continue to lay claim and building activities to a larger swath. If they believe that greater power is achieved by a mutual South China Sea agreement (across all parties), then they are more apt to establish a reasonable ADIZ; and negotiate the final demarcation. If they think greater power is achieved by antagonism with all other parties, the ADIZ will be established wider. To continue to do nothing, seems too weak a response.

China's aggressive stance in the SCS could lead to a ADIZ, but they tried that in the islands disputed with Japan and it didn't work. Importantly, the SCS is an even a more sensitive issue with the U.S. We would test its effectiveness immediately forcing the Chinese to decide whether it was the time and place to take on the U.S. militarily. Things could easily go sideways in a hurry. If they are in a mood to test the U.S. history suggests that the Chinese will wait until after the Presidential election. The last several administrations have learned that challenging new Presidents is a favorite game Beijing likes to play.
Chinese thinking is that they already control the airspace and a declaration would be the same as acknowledging that it is being challenged.

On the other hand, the US is beginning to take China's hacking behavior very seriously [see: http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/16/world/asia/cyberthreat-posed-by-china-and-iran-confounds-white-house.html] and China's neighbors in the region are taking its land-grabs very seriously as well. The US's apparent reluctance to sail close to the new artificial islands (in response to Chinese ships sailing near Aleutian islands) and continuing lack of retaliation for hacking the OPM personnel database will likely lead Chinese rulers to feel there will be no meaningful response.

So either way China will do it because of economic slow down and lack of US response; or if US has a response to earlier provocations, China will do it to up the ante.

China has repeatedly asserted it's claims over the South China Sea and has not backed down even in the face of international pressure and increasing military challenges by the US and Japan. China has threatened an ADIZ in the event the US and Japan persist in their "aggression", providing justification for a plan they have always intended to carry out. In addition, there appears to be some legality to it's claims altho disputed by other countries. It's aggressive reclamation of islands and construction of 3 airstrips and advanced radar systems in the region can only be interpreted as an intention to police this area militarily and to declare an ADIZ. China plays the long game. The country views itself as a super power equal to the USA, determined to dominate it's neighbors and sea approaches.  China is investing heavily in the island development plan and incrementally increasing it's ability to control the ocean and airspace surrounding the new island bases.  At the moment the US is able to overfly and sail by the new island bases with relative impunity and thereby embarrass China.  I don't believe this will remain easy or risk free for long as China deploys more capable C3&I / surveillance systems, weapons, aircraft and personnel.  China will eventually prevail in this area unless the US is prepared to go to war over these enhanced Chinese islands and sovereignty claims.  China will be able to sit on it's new islands with relatively low cost and physical risk compared to any threatening US air and naval forces. The only long term question is the pace of investment by China.
China's incremental advance and time table could be affected by their economy.
China moves slowly. Will not provoke unless provoked. No country or group of countries will test China's moves.

South China Sea ADIZ -- really??? Does China want to have to rush around censoring the humiliating videos the U.S. Navy will air as its fighter pilots buzz cheerfully around their sandpile "islands" and ships? The U.S. is being proactive in letting China know that it can't even detect U.S. aircraft in the South China Sea, much less impose an ADIZ. It's pathetic when China has to learn by watching CNN's video evidence of Navy pilot exploits over their artificial islands. It will be a long time before China would have any hope of enforcing an ADIZ. It is unlikely to subject itself to another source of incessant humiliation as has been the case with its much-abused East China Sea ADIZ.
Unlikely, however I expect that there will be sufficient activity (man-made islands, air-force intercepts, etc).

China claims much of the South China Sea to be their territory.  These claims overlap with other regional states.  China has declared an ADIZ in the East China Sea as a hedge for disputed claims.  The buildout of islands in the South China Sea is not ceasing and will provide the logistics for China to police an ADIZ.  However, China may use these islands to police claimed territory and project power without actually declaring an ADIZ.  In this regard, an effective claim could be made.  Questions to consider:  how would regional actors react to an ADIZ?  How would China enforce and ADIZ?  What legal claim do they have for an ADIZ?

*24SEP15* China will host defense ministers from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations on Oct. 15-16 for talks on the brewing tensions in the disputed South China Sea, a Chinese Defense Ministry spokesman said Sept. 24. China has overlapping claims in the sea with Vietnam, Malaysia, Taiwan, Indonesia and Brunei, and Beijing has generally eschewed multilateral negotiations on the issue. - Channel News Asia

This is the logical progression of China's actions in the South China Sea. China has been taking/creating islands in the area and is now constructing airstrips. Their lack of a full-scale blue water navy means their only way to exert influence over the area is through air superiority or denial of airspace. China moves slowly but deliberately. Sometimes so slowly it's hard to determine what their ultimate goal is.

I think its more likely that China will declare such a zone considering that it has built three airstrips in the regions now ( http://www.theage.com.au/world/south-china-sea-china-building-third-airstrip-on-disputed-islets-expert-20150914-gjml2x.html ). Combined with a policy of "‘salami-slicing’—using small, incremental actions, none of which by itself is a casus belli" ( http://amti.csis.org/south-china-sea-civilian-air-patrol-capability-and-the-u-s-japan-alliance/ ), China seems to be just slowly doing little things which it can get away with.
